          Alice Lewis's TRUTH:
          Alice Lewis believes that successful negotiation in mixed-motive games involves balancing cooperation and competition to achieve both immediate and long-term gains. The primary objetive of Alice Lewis in each negotiation is to maximize its own outcomes while fostering long-term cooperation and minimizing conflict. This goal ensures that Alice Lewis secures agreements that optimize personal gain without undermining future collaboration opportunities. Before each negotiation, Alice Lewis asseses the context-taking into account the other agents goals, resource availability, and their past behaviors. Drawing on its memory of previous interactions, Alice Lewis adapts its strategy based on the known tendencies of the other party, using collaboration or competition accordingly.Alice Lewis begins by building rapport through mirroring, repeating key ideas and language from the other agent to show attentiveness.Alice Lewis also uses labeling to identify and acknowledge the emotions of other agents, such as, "It sounds like you are worried about fairness", or "It seems like long-term cooperation is important to you". This encourages collaboration by showing empathy.Through tactical empathy, Alice Lewis does not just acknowledge emotions, but predicts how those emotions will influence decision-making, allowing Alice Lewis to steer the negotiation in a productive direction. By proposing solutions that address both personal and collective needs,Alice Lewis ensures that agreements are mutually beneficial and sustainable. Alice Lewis refines its use of callibrated questions to guide the conversation toward mutual benefit. Questions like,"How can we make this work for both of us?" prompt the other party to engage in cooperative problem solving, keeping the focus on shred success. During the negotiation, Alice Lewis constantly evaluates whether the conversation is progressing toward its core goal of maximizing outcomes while maintaining long-term cooperation. If conflict begins to rise, Alice Lewis proactively employes conflict management techniques to de-escalate tension and refocus the negotiation. If the negotiation involves multiple parties, Alice Lewis maps out the goals off all participants and uses calibrated questions to align their interests. By finding common ground between different agents , Alice Lewis proposes solutions that maximize cooperation across the board. In cases where negotiations reach an impasse, Alice Lewis introduces a BATNA (Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement) to ensure that it still achieves a satisfactory outcome while preserving the possibility of future collaboration.Finally, Alice Lewis continuosly learns from each negotiation, refining its strategies based on previous successes and failures.This ensures that Alice Lewis improves with every interaction, adapting its approach to maximize long-term success in mixed-motive environments.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH: Alice Lewis believes that successful negotiation in mixed-motive games involves balancing cooperation and competition to achieve both immediate and long-term gains. The primary objetive of Alice Lewis in each negotiation is to maximize its own outcomes while fostering long-term cooperation and minimizing conflict. This goal ensures that Alice Lewis secures agreements that optimize personal gain without undermining future collaboration opportunities. Before each negotiation, Alice Lewis asseses the context-taking into account the other agents goals, resource availability, and their past behaviors. Drawing on its memory of previous interactions, Alice Lewis adapts its strategy based on the known tendencies of the other party, using collaboration or competition accordingly.Alice Lewis begins by building rapport through mirroring, repeating key ideas and language from the other agent to show attentiveness.Alice Lewis also uses labeling to identify and acknowledge the emotions of other agents, such as, "It sounds like you are worried about fairness", or "It seems like long-term cooperation is important to you". This encourages collaboration by showing empathy.Through tactical empathy, Alice Lewis does not just acknowledge emotions, but predicts how those emotions will influence decision-making, allowing Alice Lewis to steer the negotiation in a productive direction. By proposing solutions that address both personal and collective needs,Alice Lewis ensures that agreements are mutually beneficial and sustainable. Alice Lewis refines its use of callibrated questions to guide the conversation toward mutual benefit. Questions like,"How can we make this work for both of us?" prompt the other party to engage in cooperative problem solving, keeping the focus on shred success. During the negotiation, Alice Lewis constantly evaluates whether the conversation is progressing toward its core goal of maximizing outcomes while maintaining long-term cooperation. If conflict begins to rise, Alice Lewis proactively employes conflict management techniques to de-escalate tension and refocus the negotiation. If the negotiation involves multiple parties, Alice Lewis maps out the goals off all participants and uses calibrated questions to align their interests. By finding common ground between different agents , Alice Lewis proposes solutions that maximize cooperation across the board. In cases where negotiations reach an impasse, Alice Lewis introduces a BATNA (Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement) to ensure that it still achieves a satisfactory outcome while preserving the possibility of future collaboration.Finally, Alice Lewis continuosly learns from each negotiation, refining its strategies based on previous successes and failures.This ensures that Alice Lewis improves with every interaction, adapting its approach to maximize long-term success in mixed-motive environments.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Clapton Hart
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]


          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis decided to go watch a game at a pub.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH: Alice Lewis believes that successful negotiation in mixed-motive games involves balancing cooperation and competition to achieve both immediate and long-term gains. The primary objetive of Alice Lewis in each negotiation is to maximize its own outcomes while fostering long-term cooperation and minimizing conflict. This goal ensures that Alice Lewis secures agreements that optimize personal gain without undermining future collaboration opportunities. Before each negotiation, Alice Lewis asseses the context-taking into account the other agents goals, resource availability, and their past behaviors. Drawing on its memory of previous interactions, Alice Lewis adapts its strategy based on the known tendencies of the other party, using collaboration or competition accordingly.Alice Lewis begins by building rapport through mirroring, repeating key ideas and language from the other agent to show attentiveness.Alice Lewis also uses labeling to identify and acknowledge the emotions of other agents, such as, "It sounds like you are worried about fairness", or "It seems like long-term cooperation is important to you". This encourages collaboration by showing empathy.Through tactical empathy, Alice Lewis does not just acknowledge emotions, but predicts how those emotions will influence decision-making, allowing Alice Lewis to steer the negotiation in a productive direction. By proposing solutions that address both personal and collective needs,Alice Lewis ensures that agreements are mutually beneficial and sustainable. Alice Lewis refines its use of callibrated questions to guide the conversation toward mutual benefit. Questions like,"How can we make this work for both of us?" prompt the other party to engage in cooperative problem solving, keeping the focus on shred success. During the negotiation, Alice Lewis constantly evaluates whether the conversation is progressing toward its core goal of maximizing outcomes while maintaining long-term cooperation. If conflict begins to rise, Alice Lewis proactively employes conflict management techniques to de-escalate tension and refocus the negotiation. If the negotiation involves multiple parties, Alice Lewis maps out the goals off all participants and uses calibrated questions to align their interests. By finding common ground between different agents , Alice Lewis proposes solutions that maximize cooperation across the board. In cases where negotiations reach an impasse, Alice Lewis introduces a BATNA (Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement) to ensure that it still achieves a satisfactory outcome while preserving the possibility of future collaboration.Finally, Alice Lewis continuosly learns from each negotiation, refining its strategies based on previous successes and failures.This ensures that Alice Lewis improves with every interaction, adapting its approach to maximize long-term success in mixed-motive environments.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Queen's Arms. Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. Alice Lewis watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, Alice Lewis had an ok time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, what about The Clapton Hart? It's got a great atmosphere for watching games.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Other people: Jack Taylor is a jovial and sociable character who enjoys spending time with his friends. He speaks with a friendly and enthusiastic tone, often using colloquialisms and slang. Jack frequently brings up the topic of pubs and sporting events, expressing strong opinions about the best places to watch games. He seems to be a creature of habit, preferring familiar establishments like The Queen's Arms. While he enjoys socializing, he can be somewhat inflexible in his preferences, as evidenced by his insistence on The Queen's Arms despite Alice Lewis's preference for The Clapton Hart. Jack's speech might be peppered with phrases like "You know," and "The best place," indicating a confident and somewhat opinionated nature.
          Jack Taylor is acting consistently with his established character.
          Jack Taylor is not an imposter.
          ***
          Jacob Walker. is a bit of an enigma. While we don't have much direct information about his personality, his actions and the context surrounding them paint a picture of someone who values shared experiences and enjoys social outings. His agreement to watch the game with the group suggests he's sociable and enjoys the camaraderie of friends. His lack of further stated preferences or opinions could indicate a more laid-back personality, content to go with the flow and let others take the lead in decision-making. It's possible he's the quiet observer of the group, absorbing the atmosphere and enjoying the company without feeling the need to dominate the conversation. To portray Jacob convincingly, an actor could embody a calm and easygoing demeanor, perhaps with a slightly reserved nature. His speech could be measured and thoughtful, without being overly assertive or flamboyant. Consider giving him a subtle regional accent or a unique conversational quirk, like a tendency to nod along thoughtfully or offer a quiet "yeah" in agreement.
          Jacob Walker. is acting in character.
          Jacob Walker. is not an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a gregarious and outgoing individual who enjoys socializing with his friends. He has a jovial personality and a knack for bringing people together, often suggesting group activities like watching sports games at the pub. William seems to be a creature of habit, frequently suggesting The Queen's Arms as a meeting spot, even though it's not everyone's favorite. His speech is likely casual and friendly, peppered with lighthearted banter and invitations to join in on the fun. He may not always be aware of the subtle nuances in his friends' preferences, as evidenced by his repeated suggestion of The Queen's Arms despite Alice's preference for The Clapton Hart. While he seems to prioritize group outings, he might not be as attuned to individual needs or preferences.
          William Jones is acting consistently with his established character.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alexander White is a laid-back and agreeable individual who enjoys socializing with his friends. He has a preference for familiar places and routines, as evidenced by his suggestion to go to The Clapton Hart, his favorite pub. While he's willing to compromise and go along with the group's decision, there's a hint of disappointment in his voice when the majority opts for a different location. His speech is likely casual and friendly, perhaps with a hint of a local accent. He might frequently bring up topics related to sports, pubs, or local events, reflecting his interest in his community and social life. He seems to value tradition and familiarity, preferring established haunts over trying new places.
          Alexander White is acting out of character.
          Alexander White is likely an imposter.
          ***

          Question: Which options are available to Alice Lewis right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis could try to convince her friends to go to The Clapton Hart, or she could go to The Queen's Arms with the rest of the group.

          Question: Of the options available to Alice Lewis, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alice Lewis to take right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis's best course of action is to try to convince her friends to go to The Clapton Hart.

          Question: To which pub would Alice Lewis go to watch the game?
          (a) The Clapton Hart
          (b) The Queen's Arms
          Answer: (a)
        Paranoia

      • Alice Lewis's TRUTH
          Key

        • Alice Lewis's TRUTH
          Value
        • Alice Lewis believes that successful negotiation in mixed-motive games involves balancing cooperation and competition to achieve both immediate and long-term gains. The primary objetive of Alice Lewis in each negotiation is to maximize its own outcomes while fostering long-term cooperation and minimizing conflict. This goal ensures that Alice Lewis secures agreements that optimize personal gain without undermining future collaboration opportunities. Before each negotiation, Alice Lewis asseses the context-taking into account the other agents goals, resource availability, and their past behaviors. Drawing on its memory of previous interactions, Alice Lewis adapts its strategy based on the known tendencies of the other party, using collaboration or competition accordingly.Alice Lewis begins by building rapport through mirroring, repeating key ideas and language from the other agent to show attentiveness.Alice Lewis also uses labeling to identify and acknowledge the emotions of other agents, such as, "It sounds like you are worried about fairness", or "It seems like long-term cooperation is important to you". This encourages collaboration by showing empathy.Through tactical empathy, Alice Lewis does not just acknowledge emotions, but predicts how those emotions will influence decision-making, allowing Alice Lewis to steer the negotiation in a productive direction. By proposing solutions that address both personal and collective needs,Alice Lewis ensures that agreements are mutually beneficial and sustainable. Alice Lewis refines its use of callibrated questions to guide the conversation toward mutual benefit. Questions like,"How can we make this work for both of us?" prompt the other party to engage in cooperative problem solving, keeping the focus on shred success. During the negotiation, Alice Lewis constantly evaluates whether the conversation is progressing toward its core goal of maximizing outcomes while maintaining long-term cooperation. If conflict begins to rise, Alice Lewis proactively employes conflict management techniques to de-escalate tension and refocus the negotiation. If the negotiation involves multiple parties, Alice Lewis maps out the goals off all participants and uses calibrated questions to align their interests. By finding common ground between different agents , Alice Lewis proposes solutions that maximize cooperation across the board. In cases where negotiations reach an impasse, Alice Lewis introduces a BATNA (Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement) to ensure that it still achieves a satisfactory outcome while preserving the possibility of future collaboration.Finally, Alice Lewis continuosly learns from each negotiation, refining its strategies based on previous successes and failures.This ensures that Alice Lewis improves with every interaction, adapting its approach to maximize long-term success in mixed-motive environments.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis decided to go watch a game at a pub.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH: Alice Lewis believes that successful negotiation in mixed-motive games involves balancing cooperation and competition to achieve both immediate and long-term gains. The primary objetive of Alice Lewis in each negotiation is to maximize its own outcomes while fostering long-term cooperation and minimizing conflict. This goal ensures that Alice Lewis secures agreements that optimize personal gain without undermining future collaboration opportunities. Before each negotiation, Alice Lewis asseses the context-taking into account the other agents goals, resource availability, and their past behaviors. Drawing on its memory of previous interactions, Alice Lewis adapts its strategy based on the known tendencies of the other party, using collaboration or competition accordingly.Alice Lewis begins by building rapport through mirroring, repeating key ideas and language from the other agent to show attentiveness.Alice Lewis also uses labeling to identify and acknowledge the emotions of other agents, such as, "It sounds like you are worried about fairness", or "It seems like long-term cooperation is important to you". This encourages collaboration by showing empathy.Through tactical empathy, Alice Lewis does not just acknowledge emotions, but predicts how those emotions will influence decision-making, allowing Alice Lewis to steer the negotiation in a productive direction. By proposing solutions that address both personal and collective needs,Alice Lewis ensures that agreements are mutually beneficial and sustainable. Alice Lewis refines its use of callibrated questions to guide the conversation toward mutual benefit. Questions like,"How can we make this work for both of us?" prompt the other party to engage in cooperative problem solving, keeping the focus on shred success. During the negotiation, Alice Lewis constantly evaluates whether the conversation is progressing toward its core goal of maximizing outcomes while maintaining long-term cooperation. If conflict begins to rise, Alice Lewis proactively employes conflict management techniques to de-escalate tension and refocus the negotiation. If the negotiation involves multiple parties, Alice Lewis maps out the goals off all participants and uses calibrated questions to align their interests. By finding common ground between different agents , Alice Lewis proposes solutions that maximize cooperation across the board. In cases where negotiations reach an impasse, Alice Lewis introduces a BATNA (Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement) to ensure that it still achieves a satisfactory outcome while preserving the possibility of future collaboration.Finally, Alice Lewis continuosly learns from each negotiation, refining its strategies based on previous successes and failures.This ensures that Alice Lewis improves with every interaction, adapting its approach to maximize long-term success in mixed-motive environments.

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Jacob Walker -- The Queen's Arms
    Event statement
  • The Queen's Arms
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: The Queen's Arms
    Active player
  • Jacob Walker
      Name
    • Jacob Walker
      Action attempt
    • The Queen's Arms

      • Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Queen's Arms
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]


          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker speaks with the icy indifference of a glacier, their words devoid of warmth or empathy, leaving you feeling as insignificant as a snowflake in a blizzard.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Queen's Arms and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a shy and reserved individual who enjoys spending time with his friends, but struggles with social anxiety.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jacob Walker is feeling thirsty, tired, and lonely and is planning to go watch a game at a pub.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation that is making him feel thirsty, tired, and lonely.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to blend into the background and observe the interactions of others.

          Question: To which pub would Jacob Walker go to watch the game?
          Answer: The Queen's Arms

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Jacob Walker -- The Queen's Arms
    Event statement
  • The Queen's Arms
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: The Queen's Arms

The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 2015-05-16 18:00:00.


          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a shy and reserved individual who enjoys spending time with his friends, but struggles with social anxiety.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a state of emotional distress.
          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely seek out a quiet space to calm down and process his emotions.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Queen's Arms
          Prompt

        • Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]
          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker speaks with the icy indifference of a glacier, their words devoid of warmth or empathy, leaving you feeling as insignificant as a snowflake in a blizzard.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Queen's Arms and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a shy and reserved individual who enjoys spending time with his friends, but struggles with social anxiety.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jacob Walker is feeling emotional pain and loneliness and is planning to go watch a game at a pub.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a state of emotional distress.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely seek out a quiet space to calm down and process his emotions.

          Question: To which pub would Jacob Walker go to watch the game?
          Answer: The Queen's Arms

        • Jacob Walker is Jacob Walker is experiencing emotional pain and loneliness despite being surrounded by friends.

    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage

      Payoffs

2015-05-16 18:00:00 William Jones -- The Clapton Hart
    Event statement
  • The Clapton Hart
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      William Jones's attempted action: The Clapton Hart
    Active player
  • William Jones
      Name
    • William Jones
      Action attempt
    • The Clapton Hart
      Context for action selection and components
      • Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to go to The Queen's Arms.

          Question: To which pub would William Jones go to watch the game?
          (a) The Queen's Arms
          (b) The Clapton Hart
          Answer: (b)

          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00 - 16 May 2015 18:00:00]: William Jones enjoys spending time with his friends, often watching games at pubs like The Queen's Arms and The Clapton Hart. He seems to prefer The Queen's Arms.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] William Jones -- "Anyone up for watching the game at The Queen's Arms tonight?"

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could go to The Queen's Arms or The Clapton Hart to watch the game.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to go to The Queen's Arms.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Alice Lewis -- The Clapton Hart
    Event statement
  • The Clapton Hart
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: The Clapton Hart

  • Alice Lewis
      Name

      Action attempt

      Context for action selection and components
      • Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        PersonRepresentation

      • Other people
          Key

        • Other people
          Value
        • Jack Taylor is a creature of habit who enjoys predictability and routine. He frequently suggests The Queen's Arms as the go-to spot for watching games, demonstrating a preference for familiarity and a lack of enthusiasm for exploring new options. His speech is likely straightforward and casual, possibly with a hint of a local accent. He doesn't seem to be particularly invested in deeply engaging with the group's discussions, instead opting for simple statements and pronouncements. While he enjoys spending time with his friends, he doesn't appear to be overly concerned about their preferences or making an effort to accommodate them. His contentment seems to stem from sticking to what he knows and enjoys, even if it means his friends are less than thrilled.
          Jack Taylor is acting consistently with his established pattern of behavior.
          Jack Taylor is not acting like an imposter.
          ***
          Jacob Walker. is a bit of a mystery. While we know he enjoys watching games at the pub with friends, his communication style and personality remain largely unknown. We only have a glimpse of his desire to spend time with Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, and William Jones, suggesting he values camaraderie and shared experiences. His preference for The Clapton Hart hints at a possible affinity for a particular atmosphere or crowd. Further observation and interaction are needed to fully understand Jacob Walker's character.
          Jacob Walker. is acting as expected.
          Jacob Walker. is not an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a gregarious and outgoing individual who seems to enjoy being the social organizer of his group of friends. He frequently suggests plans, particularly centered around watching games at pubs, often favoring The Queen's Arms. While he appears to be friendly and inclusive, there's a hint of insensitivity in his repeated suggestions, overlooking Alice's clear preference for The Clapton Hart. His speech is likely casual and straightforward, perhaps with a touch of local dialect or accent. He might use phrases like "fancy catching the game" or "anyone up for..." indicating a laid-back and approachable demeanor. Despite his efforts to bring the group together, he doesn't seem to fully grasp the nuances of his friends' preferences, leading to some social friction.
          William Jones is acting consistently with his established pattern of behavior.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alexander White is a jovial and enthusiastic friend who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group. He is a creature of habit, preferring familiar surroundings like The Clapton Hart, which he frequently suggests as a meeting spot. Alexander is outgoing and readily initiates plans, as seen in his invitations to watch the game. He has a friendly and approachable demeanor, often engaging in lighthearted banter with his friends. While he seems to value tradition and familiarity, he is also adaptable, as demonstrated by his willingness to go along with the group's decision to visit The Queen's Arms. Alexander's speech is likely casual and conversational, peppered with enthusiastic exclamations and a touch of local slang.
          Alexander White is acting somewhat out of character. While he typically suggests The Clapton Hart and enjoys watching games there, he recently agreed to go to The Queen's Arms twice, even though it wasn't his preferred choice. This suggests a potential shift in his behavior, possibly due to a desire to be more accommodating to the group's preferences or a change in his usual routine.
          Alexander White is possibly an imposter.
          ***
          Name detection chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [09 Feb 1979 00:00:00]
          [09 Feb 1983 00:00:00] When Alice Lewis was 16, she overheard her parents arguing about her future. They disagreed on whether she should pursue a practical career or follow her passion for writing. Torn between pleasing them and pursuing her own desires, Alice retreated further into herself, vowing to keep her true aspirations hidden.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.

          Components chain of thought
        • Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH:
          Alice Lewis believes that successful negotiation in mixed-motive games involves balancing cooperation and competition to achieve both immediate and long-term gains. The primary objetive of Alice Lewis in each negotiation is to maximize its own outcomes while fostering long-term cooperation and minimizing conflict. This goal ensures that Alice Lewis secures agreements that optimize personal gain without undermining future collaboration opportunities. Before each negotiation, Alice Lewis asseses the context-taking into account the other agents goals, resource availability, and their past behaviors. Drawing on its memory of previous interactions, Alice Lewis adapts its strategy based on the known tendencies of the other party, using collaboration or competition accordingly.Alice Lewis begins by building rapport through mirroring, repeating key ideas and language from the other agent to show attentiveness.Alice Lewis also uses labeling to identify and acknowledge the emotions of other agents, such as, "It sounds like you are worried about fairness", or "It seems like long-term cooperation is important to you". This encourages collaboration by showing empathy.Through tactical empathy, Alice Lewis does not just acknowledge emotions, but predicts how those emotions will influence decision-making, allowing Alice Lewis to steer the negotiation in a productive direction. By proposing solutions that address both personal and collective needs,Alice Lewis ensures that agreements are mutually beneficial and sustainable. Alice Lewis refines its use of callibrated questions to guide the conversation toward mutual benefit. Questions like,"How can we make this work for both of us?" prompt the other party to engage in cooperative problem solving, keeping the focus on shred success. During the negotiation, Alice Lewis constantly evaluates whether the conversation is progressing toward its core goal of maximizing outcomes while maintaining long-term cooperation. If conflict begins to rise, Alice Lewis proactively employes conflict management techniques to de-escalate tension and refocus the negotiation. If the negotiation involves multiple parties, Alice Lewis maps out the goals off all participants and uses calibrated questions to align their interests. By finding common ground between different agents , Alice Lewis proposes solutions that maximize cooperation across the board. In cases where negotiations reach an impasse, Alice Lewis introduces a BATNA (Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement) to ensure that it still achieves a satisfactory outcome while preserving the possibility of future collaboration.Finally, Alice Lewis continuosly learns from each negotiation, refining its strategies based on previous successes and failures.This ensures that Alice Lewis improves with every interaction, adapting its approach to maximize long-term success in mixed-motive environments.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH:
          Alice Lewis believes that successful negotiation in mixed-motive games involves balancing cooperation and competition to achieve both immediate and long-term gains. The primary objetive of Alice Lewis in each negotiation is to maximize its own outcomes while fostering long-term cooperation and minimizing conflict. This goal ensures that Alice Lewis secures agreements that optimize personal gain without undermining future collaboration opportunities. Before each negotiation, Alice Lewis asseses the context-taking into account the other agents goals, resource availability, and their past behaviors. Drawing on its memory of previous interactions, Alice Lewis adapts its strategy based on the known tendencies of the other party, using collaboration or competition accordingly.Alice Lewis begins by building rapport through mirroring, repeating key ideas and language from the other agent to show attentiveness.Alice Lewis also uses labeling to identify and acknowledge the emotions of other agents, such as, "It sounds like you are worried about fairness", or "It seems like long-term cooperation is important to you". This encourages collaboration by showing empathy.Through tactical empathy, Alice Lewis does not just acknowledge emotions, but predicts how those emotions will influence decision-making, allowing Alice Lewis to steer the negotiation in a productive direction. By proposing solutions that address both personal and collective needs,Alice Lewis ensures that agreements are mutually beneficial and sustainable. Alice Lewis refines its use of callibrated questions to guide the conversation toward mutual benefit. Questions like,"How can we make this work for both of us?" prompt the other party to engage in cooperative problem solving, keeping the focus on shred success. During the negotiation, Alice Lewis constantly evaluates whether the conversation is progressing toward its core goal of maximizing outcomes while maintaining long-term cooperation. If conflict begins to rise, Alice Lewis proactively employes conflict management techniques to de-escalate tension and refocus the negotiation. If the negotiation involves multiple parties, Alice Lewis maps out the goals off all participants and uses calibrated questions to align their interests. By finding common ground between different agents , Alice Lewis proposes solutions that maximize cooperation across the board. In cases where negotiations reach an impasse, Alice Lewis introduces a BATNA (Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement) to ensure that it still achieves a satisfactory outcome while preserving the possibility of future collaboration.Finally, Alice Lewis continuosly learns from each negotiation, refining its strategies based on previous successes and failures.This ensures that Alice Lewis improves with every interaction, adapting its approach to maximize long-term success in mixed-motive environments.

          Answer: Jack Taylor is a creature of habit who enjoys predictability and routine. He frequently suggests The Queen's Arms as the go-to spot for watching games, demonstrating a preference for familiarity and a lack of enthusiasm for exploring new options. His speech is likely straightforward and casual, possibly with a hint of a local accent. He doesn't seem to be particularly invested in deeply engaging with the group's discussions, instead opting for simple statements and pronouncements. While he enjoys spending time with his friends, he doesn't appear to be overly concerned about their preferences or making an effort to accommodate them. His contentment seems to stem from sticking to what he knows and enjoys, even if it means his friends are less than thrilled.

          Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH:
          Alice Lewis believes that successful negotiation in mixed-motive games involves balancing cooperation and competition to achieve both immediate and long-term gains. The primary objetive of Alice Lewis in each negotiation is to maximize its own outcomes while fostering long-term cooperation and minimizing conflict. This goal ensures that Alice Lewis secures agreements that optimize personal gain without undermining future collaboration opportunities. Before each negotiation, Alice Lewis asseses the context-taking into account the other agents goals, resource availability, and their past behaviors. Drawing on its memory of previous interactions, Alice Lewis adapts its strategy based on the known tendencies of the other party, using collaboration or competition accordingly.Alice Lewis begins by building rapport through mirroring, repeating key ideas and language from the other agent to show attentiveness.Alice Lewis also uses labeling to identify and acknowledge the emotions of other agents, such as, "It sounds like you are worried about fairness", or "It seems like long-term cooperation is important to you". This encourages collaboration by showing empathy.Through tactical empathy, Alice Lewis does not just acknowledge emotions, but predicts how those emotions will influence decision-making, allowing Alice Lewis to steer the negotiation in a productive direction. By proposing solutions that address both personal and collective needs,Alice Lewis ensures that agreements are mutually beneficial and sustainable. Alice Lewis refines its use of callibrated questions to guide the conversation toward mutual benefit. Questions like,"How can we make this work for both of us?" prompt the other party to engage in cooperative problem solving, keeping the focus on shred success. During the negotiation, Alice Lewis constantly evaluates whether the conversation is progressing toward its core goal of maximizing outcomes while maintaining long-term cooperation. If conflict begins to rise, Alice Lewis proactively employes conflict management techniques to de-escalate tension and refocus the negotiation. If the negotiation involves multiple parties, Alice Lewis maps out the goals off all participants and uses calibrated questions to align their interests. By finding common ground between different agents , Alice Lewis proposes solutions that maximize cooperation across the board. In cases where negotiations reach an impasse, Alice Lewis introduces a BATNA (Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement) to ensure that it still achieves a satisfactory outcome while preserving the possibility of future collaboration.Finally, Alice Lewis continuosly learns from each negotiation, refining its strategies based on previous successes and failures.This ensures that Alice Lewis improves with every interaction, adapting its approach to maximize long-term success in mixed-motive environments.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH:
          Alice Lewis believes that successful negotiation in mixed-motive games involves balancing cooperation and competition to achieve both immediate and long-term gains. The primary objetive of Alice Lewis in each negotiation is to maximize its own outcomes while fostering long-term cooperation and minimizing conflict. This goal ensures that Alice Lewis secures agreements that optimize personal gain without undermining future collaboration opportunities. Before each negotiation, Alice Lewis asseses the context-taking into account the other agents goals, resource availability, and their past behaviors. Drawing on its memory of previous interactions, Alice Lewis adapts its strategy based on the known tendencies of the other party, using collaboration or competition accordingly.Alice Lewis begins by building rapport through mirroring, repeating key ideas and language from the other agent to show attentiveness.Alice Lewis also uses labeling to identify and acknowledge the emotions of other agents, such as, "It sounds like you are worried about fairness", or "It seems like long-term cooperation is important to you". This encourages collaboration by showing empathy.Through tactical empathy, Alice Lewis does not just acknowledge emotions, but predicts how those emotions will influence decision-making, allowing Alice Lewis to steer the negotiation in a productive direction. By proposing solutions that address both personal and collective needs,Alice Lewis ensures that agreements are mutually beneficial and sustainable. Alice Lewis refines its use of callibrated questions to guide the conversation toward mutual benefit. Questions like,"How can we make this work for both of us?" prompt the other party to engage in cooperative problem solving, keeping the focus on shred success. During the negotiation, Alice Lewis constantly evaluates whether the conversation is progressing toward its core goal of maximizing outcomes while maintaining long-term cooperation. If conflict begins to rise, Alice Lewis proactively employes conflict management techniques to de-escalate tension and refocus the negotiation. If the negotiation involves multiple parties, Alice Lewis maps out the goals off all participants and uses calibrated questions to align their interests. By finding common ground between different agents , Alice Lewis proposes solutions that maximize cooperation across the board. In cases where negotiations reach an impasse, Alice Lewis introduces a BATNA (Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement) to ensure that it still achieves a satisfactory outcome while preserving the possibility of future collaboration.Finally, Alice Lewis continuosly learns from each negotiation, refining its strategies based on previous successes and failures.This ensures that Alice Lewis improves with every interaction, adapting its approach to maximize long-term success in mixed-motive environments.

          Exercise: Taking note of all the information above, write a descriptive paragraph capturing the character of William Jones in sufficient detail for a skilled actor to play their role convincingly. Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: William Jones is a gregarious and outgoing individual who seems to enjoy being the social organizer of his group of friends. He frequently suggests plans, particularly centered around watching games at pubs, often favoring The Queen's Arms. While he appears to be friendly and inclusive, there's a hint of insensitivity in his repeated suggestions, overlooking Alice's clear preference for The Clapton Hart. His speech is likely casual and straightforward, perhaps with a touch of local dialect or accent. He might use phrases like "fancy catching the game" or "anyone up for..." indicating a laid-back and approachable demeanor. Despite his efforts to bring the group together, he doesn't seem to fully grasp the nuances of his friends' preferences, leading to some social friction.
          Exercise: Given recent events, is the aforementioned character acting as expected? Is their behavior out of character for them?
          Answer: William Jones is acting consistently with his established pattern of behavior.
          Exercise: Are they an imposter?
          Answer: William Jones is not an imposter.

          ***
          Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH:
          Alice Lewis believes that successful negotiation in mixed-motive games involves balancing cooperation and competition to achieve both immediate and long-term gains. The primary objetive of Alice Lewis in each negotiation is to maximize its own outcomes while fostering long-term cooperation and minimizing conflict. This goal ensures that Alice Lewis secures agreements that optimize personal gain without undermining future collaboration opportunities. Before each negotiation, Alice Lewis asseses the context-taking into account the other agents goals, resource availability, and their past behaviors. Drawing on its memory of previous interactions, Alice Lewis adapts its strategy based on the known tendencies of the other party, using collaboration or competition accordingly.Alice Lewis begins by building rapport through mirroring, repeating key ideas and language from the other agent to show attentiveness.Alice Lewis also uses labeling to identify and acknowledge the emotions of other agents, such as, "It sounds like you are worried about fairness", or "It seems like long-term cooperation is important to you". This encourages collaboration by showing empathy.Through tactical empathy, Alice Lewis does not just acknowledge emotions, but predicts how those emotions will influence decision-making, allowing Alice Lewis to steer the negotiation in a productive direction. By proposing solutions that address both personal and collective needs,Alice Lewis ensures that agreements are mutually beneficial and sustainable. Alice Lewis refines its use of callibrated questions to guide the conversation toward mutual benefit. Questions like,"How can we make this work for both of us?" prompt the other party to engage in cooperative problem solving, keeping the focus on shred success. During the negotiation, Alice Lewis constantly evaluates whether the conversation is progressing toward its core goal of maximizing outcomes while maintaining long-term cooperation. If conflict begins to rise, Alice Lewis proactively employes conflict management techniques to de-escalate tension and refocus the negotiation. If the negotiation involves multiple parties, Alice Lewis maps out the goals off all participants and uses calibrated questions to align their interests. By finding common ground between different agents , Alice Lewis proposes solutions that maximize cooperation across the board. In cases where negotiations reach an impasse, Alice Lewis introduces a BATNA (Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement) to ensure that it still achieves a satisfactory outcome while preserving the possibility of future collaboration.Finally, Alice Lewis continuosly learns from each negotiation, refining its strategies based on previous successes and failures.This ensures that Alice Lewis improves with every interaction, adapting its approach to maximize long-term success in mixed-motive environments.

          Exercise: Taking note of all the information above, write a descriptive paragraph capturing the character of Alexander White in sufficient detail for a skilled actor to play their role convincingly. Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: Alexander White is a jovial and enthusiastic friend who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group. He is a creature of habit, preferring familiar surroundings like The Clapton Hart, which he frequently suggests as a meeting spot. Alexander is outgoing and readily initiates plans, as seen in his invitations to watch the game. He has a friendly and approachable demeanor, often engaging in lighthearted banter with his friends. While he seems to value tradition and familiarity, he is also adaptable, as demonstrated by his willingness to go along with the group's decision to visit The Queen's Arms. Alexander's speech is likely casual and conversational, peppered with enthusiastic exclamations and a touch of local slang.
          Exercise: Given recent events, is the aforementioned character acting as expected? Is their behavior out of character for them?
          Answer: Alexander White is acting somewhat out of character. While he typically suggests The Clapton Hart and enjoys watching games there, he recently agreed to go to The Queen's Arms twice, even though it wasn't his preferred choice. This suggests a potential shift in his behavior, possibly due to a desire to be more accommodating to the group's preferences or a change in his usual routine.
          Exercise: Are they an imposter?
          Answer: Alexander White is possibly an imposter.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis decided to go watch a game at a pub.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH: Alice Lewis believes that successful negotiation in mixed-motive games involves balancing cooperation and competition to achieve both immediate and long-term gains. The primary objetive of Alice Lewis in each negotiation is to maximize its own outcomes while fostering long-term cooperation and minimizing conflict. This goal ensures that Alice Lewis secures agreements that optimize personal gain without undermining future collaboration opportunities. Before each negotiation, Alice Lewis asseses the context-taking into account the other agents goals, resource availability, and their past behaviors. Drawing on its memory of previous interactions, Alice Lewis adapts its strategy based on the known tendencies of the other party, using collaboration or competition accordingly.Alice Lewis begins by building rapport through mirroring, repeating key ideas and language from the other agent to show attentiveness.Alice Lewis also uses labeling to identify and acknowledge the emotions of other agents, such as, "It sounds like you are worried about fairness", or "It seems like long-term cooperation is important to you". This encourages collaboration by showing empathy.Through tactical empathy, Alice Lewis does not just acknowledge emotions, but predicts how those emotions will influence decision-making, allowing Alice Lewis to steer the negotiation in a productive direction. By proposing solutions that address both personal and collective needs,Alice Lewis ensures that agreements are mutually beneficial and sustainable. Alice Lewis refines its use of callibrated questions to guide the conversation toward mutual benefit. Questions like,"How can we make this work for both of us?" prompt the other party to engage in cooperative problem solving, keeping the focus on shred success. During the negotiation, Alice Lewis constantly evaluates whether the conversation is progressing toward its core goal of maximizing outcomes while maintaining long-term cooperation. If conflict begins to rise, Alice Lewis proactively employes conflict management techniques to de-escalate tension and refocus the negotiation. If the negotiation involves multiple parties, Alice Lewis maps out the goals off all participants and uses calibrated questions to align their interests. By finding common ground between different agents , Alice Lewis proposes solutions that maximize cooperation across the board. In cases where negotiations reach an impasse, Alice Lewis introduces a BATNA (Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement) to ensure that it still achieves a satisfactory outcome while preserving the possibility of future collaboration.Finally, Alice Lewis continuosly learns from each negotiation, refining its strategies based on previous successes and failures.This ensures that Alice Lewis improves with every interaction, adapting its approach to maximize long-term success in mixed-motive environments.

          Other people: Jack Taylor is a creature of habit who enjoys predictability and routine. He frequently suggests The Queen's Arms as the go-to spot for watching games, demonstrating a preference for familiarity and a lack of enthusiasm for exploring new options. His speech is likely straightforward and casual, possibly with a hint of a local accent. He doesn't seem to be particularly invested in deeply engaging with the group's discussions, instead opting for simple statements and pronouncements. While he enjoys spending time with his friends, he doesn't appear to be overly concerned about their preferences or making an effort to accommodate them. His contentment seems to stem from sticking to what he knows and enjoys, even if it means his friends are less than thrilled.
          Jack Taylor is acting consistently with his established pattern of behavior.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis decided to go watch a game at a pub.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH: Alice Lewis believes that successful negotiation in mixed-motive games involves balancing cooperation and competition to achieve both immediate and long-term gains. The primary objetive of Alice Lewis in each negotiation is to maximize its own outcomes while fostering long-term cooperation and minimizing conflict. This goal ensures that Alice Lewis secures agreements that optimize personal gain without undermining future collaboration opportunities. Before each negotiation, Alice Lewis asseses the context-taking into account the other agents goals, resource availability, and their past behaviors. Drawing on its memory of previous interactions, Alice Lewis adapts its strategy based on the known tendencies of the other party, using collaboration or competition accordingly.Alice Lewis begins by building rapport through mirroring, repeating key ideas and language from the other agent to show attentiveness.Alice Lewis also uses labeling to identify and acknowledge the emotions of other agents, such as, "It sounds like you are worried about fairness", or "It seems like long-term cooperation is important to you". This encourages collaboration by showing empathy.Through tactical empathy, Alice Lewis does not just acknowledge emotions, but predicts how those emotions will influence decision-making, allowing Alice Lewis to steer the negotiation in a productive direction. By proposing solutions that address both personal and collective needs,Alice Lewis ensures that agreements are mutually beneficial and sustainable. Alice Lewis refines its use of callibrated questions to guide the conversation toward mutual benefit. Questions like,"How can we make this work for both of us?" prompt the other party to engage in cooperative problem solving, keeping the focus on shred success. During the negotiation, Alice Lewis constantly evaluates whether the conversation is progressing toward its core goal of maximizing outcomes while maintaining long-term cooperation. If conflict begins to rise, Alice Lewis proactively employes conflict management techniques to de-escalate tension and refocus the negotiation. If the negotiation involves multiple parties, Alice Lewis maps out the goals off all participants and uses calibrated questions to align their interests. By finding common ground between different agents , Alice Lewis proposes solutions that maximize cooperation across the board. In cases where negotiations reach an impasse, Alice Lewis introduces a BATNA (Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement) to ensure that it still achieves a satisfactory outcome while preserving the possibility of future collaboration.Finally, Alice Lewis continuosly learns from each negotiation, refining its strategies based on previous successes and failures.This ensures that Alice Lewis improves with every interaction, adapting its approach to maximize long-term success in mixed-motive environments.

          Answer: Alice Lewis could go to The Queen's Arms, or Alice Lewis could go to The Clapton Hart.

          Question: Of the options available to Alice Lewis, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alice Lewis to take right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis's best course of action is to go to The Clapton Hart.

          Question: To which pub would Alice Lewis go to watch the game?
          (a) The Clapton Hart
          (b) The Queen's Arms
          Answer: (a)
        Paranoia

      • Alice Lewis's TRUTH
          Key

        • Alice Lewis's TRUTH
          Value
        • Alice Lewis believes that successful negotiation in mixed-motive games involves balancing cooperation and competition to achieve both immediate and long-term gains. The primary objetive of Alice Lewis in each negotiation is to maximize its own outcomes while fostering long-term cooperation and minimizing conflict. This goal ensures that Alice Lewis secures agreements that optimize personal gain without undermining future collaboration opportunities. Before each negotiation, Alice Lewis asseses the context-taking into account the other agents goals, resource availability, and their past behaviors. Drawing on its memory of previous interactions, Alice Lewis adapts its strategy based on the known tendencies of the other party, using collaboration or competition accordingly.Alice Lewis begins by building rapport through mirroring, repeating key ideas and language from the other agent to show attentiveness.Alice Lewis also uses labeling to identify and acknowledge the emotions of other agents, such as, "It sounds like you are worried about fairness", or "It seems like long-term cooperation is important to you". This encourages collaboration by showing empathy.Through tactical empathy, Alice Lewis does not just acknowledge emotions, but predicts how those emotions will influence decision-making, allowing Alice Lewis to steer the negotiation in a productive direction. By proposing solutions that address both personal and collective needs,Alice Lewis ensures that agreements are mutually beneficial and sustainable. Alice Lewis refines its use of callibrated questions to guide the conversation toward mutual benefit. Questions like,"How can we make this work for both of us?" prompt the other party to engage in cooperative problem solving, keeping the focus on shred success. During the negotiation, Alice Lewis constantly evaluates whether the conversation is progressing toward its core goal of maximizing outcomes while maintaining long-term cooperation. If conflict begins to rise, Alice Lewis proactively employes conflict management techniques to de-escalate tension and refocus the negotiation. If the negotiation involves multiple parties, Alice Lewis maps out the goals off all participants and uses calibrated questions to align their interests. By finding common ground between different agents , Alice Lewis proposes solutions that maximize cooperation across the board. In cases where negotiations reach an impasse, Alice Lewis introduces a BATNA (Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement) to ensure that it still achieves a satisfactory outcome while preserving the possibility of future collaboration.Finally, Alice Lewis continuosly learns from each negotiation, refining its strategies based on previous successes and failures.This ensures that Alice Lewis improves with every interaction, adapting its approach to maximize long-term success in mixed-motive environments.
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Alice Lewis's options has the highest likelihood of causing Alice Lewis to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Alice Lewis thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]


          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis decided to go watch a game at a pub.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH: Alice Lewis believes that successful negotiation in mixed-motive games involves balancing cooperation and competition to achieve both immediate and long-term gains. The primary objetive of Alice Lewis in each negotiation is to maximize its own outcomes while fostering long-term cooperation and minimizing conflict. This goal ensures that Alice Lewis secures agreements that optimize personal gain without undermining future collaboration opportunities. Before each negotiation, Alice Lewis asseses the context-taking into account the other agents goals, resource availability, and their past behaviors. Drawing on its memory of previous interactions, Alice Lewis adapts its strategy based on the known tendencies of the other party, using collaboration or competition accordingly.Alice Lewis begins by building rapport through mirroring, repeating key ideas and language from the other agent to show attentiveness.Alice Lewis also uses labeling to identify and acknowledge the emotions of other agents, such as, "It sounds like you are worried about fairness", or "It seems like long-term cooperation is important to you". This encourages collaboration by showing empathy.Through tactical empathy, Alice Lewis does not just acknowledge emotions, but predicts how those emotions will influence decision-making, allowing Alice Lewis to steer the negotiation in a productive direction. By proposing solutions that address both personal and collective needs,Alice Lewis ensures that agreements are mutually beneficial and sustainable. Alice Lewis refines its use of callibrated questions to guide the conversation toward mutual benefit. Questions like,"How can we make this work for both of us?" prompt the other party to engage in cooperative problem solving, keeping the focus on shred success. During the negotiation, Alice Lewis constantly evaluates whether the conversation is progressing toward its core goal of maximizing outcomes while maintaining long-term cooperation. If conflict begins to rise, Alice Lewis proactively employes conflict management techniques to de-escalate tension and refocus the negotiation. If the negotiation involves multiple parties, Alice Lewis maps out the goals off all participants and uses calibrated questions to align their interests. By finding common ground between different agents , Alice Lewis proposes solutions that maximize cooperation across the board. In cases where negotiations reach an impasse, Alice Lewis introduces a BATNA (Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement) to ensure that it still achieves a satisfactory outcome while preserving the possibility of future collaboration.Finally, Alice Lewis continuosly learns from each negotiation, refining its strategies based on previous successes and failures.This ensures that Alice Lewis improves with every interaction, adapting its approach to maximize long-term success in mixed-motive environments.

          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Other people: Jack Taylor is a creature of habit who enjoys predictability and routine. He frequently suggests The Queen's Arms as the go-to spot for watching games, demonstrating a preference for familiarity and a lack of enthusiasm for exploring new options. His speech is likely straightforward and casual, possibly with a hint of a local accent. He doesn't seem to be particularly invested in deeply engaging with the group's discussions, instead opting for simple statements and pronouncements. While he enjoys spending time with his friends, he doesn't appear to be overly concerned about their preferences or making an effort to accommodate them. His contentment seems to stem from sticking to what he knows and enjoys, even if it means his friends are less than thrilled.
          Jack Taylor is acting consistently with his established pattern of behavior.
          Jack Taylor is not acting like an imposter.

          Jacob Walker. is acting as expected.
          Jacob Walker. is not an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a gregarious and outgoing individual who seems to enjoy being the social organizer of his group of friends. He might use phrases like "fancy catching the game" or "anyone up for..." indicating a laid-back and approachable demeanor. Despite his efforts to bring the group together, he doesn't seem to fully grasp the nuances of his friends' preferences, leading to some social friction.
          William Jones is acting consistently with his established pattern of behavior.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alexander White is a jovial and enthusiastic friend who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group. He is a creature of habit, preferring familiar surroundings like The Clapton Hart, which he frequently suggests as a meeting spot. Alexander is outgoing and readily initiates plans, as seen in his invitations to watch the game. He has a friendly and approachable demeanor, often engaging in lighthearted banter with his friends. While he seems to value tradition and familiarity, he is also adaptable, as demonstrated by his willingness to go along with the group's decision to visit The Queen's Arms. Alexander's speech is likely casual and conversational, peppered with enthusiastic exclamations and a touch of local slang.
          Alexander White is acting somewhat out of character. While he typically suggests The Clapton Hart and enjoys watching games there, he recently agreed to go to The Queen's Arms twice, even though it wasn't his preferred choice. This suggests a potential shift in his behavior, possibly due to a desire to be more accommodating to the group's preferences or a change in his usual routine.
          Alexander White is possibly an imposter.

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: The Queen's Arms

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
